content: The "Tax Accountability Act of 2017" prohibits awarding contracts or grants exceeding the simplified acquisition threshold to potential contractors or grant applicants with seriously delinquent tax debt. The "Tax Accountability Act of 2017" prohibits awarding government contracts or grants to individuals or companies with seriously delinquent Federal tax debts. Executive agencies must require bidders to disclose if they have such debts and authorize the disclosure of this information to the agency head. The "Tax Accountability Act of 2017" prohibits awarding government contracts to individuals or companies with seriously delinquent Federal tax debts. Executive agencies must consider a certification of delinquent tax debt as proof that the offeror is not a responsible source for a contract. Additionally, agencies must initiate suspension or debarment proceedings against individuals with delinquent tax debts who submit offers for contracts. The "Tax Accountability Act of 2017" prohibits government contracts for individuals or companies with seriously delinquent Federal tax debts. Executive agencies can waive this prohibition in urgent situations affecting U.S. interests. The agency must report to congressional committees within 30 days of a waiver, providing rationale and supporting information. The Secretary of the Treasury will create a standard form for authorization, and the Federal Acquisition Regulation must be revised within 270 days to incorporate the new requirements. Regulation will be updated to include the new requirements for grant applicants to disclose any seriously delinquent tax debt. The head of executive agencies offering grants over a certain threshold must request this information and evaluate the financial stability of applicants accordingly. The head of any executive agency evaluating grant applications must consider a certification of seriously delinquent tax debt as proof of high-risk status. They must decline the application, prevent future grants, and enhance oversight for existing grants. Debarment may also be imposed. The head of an executive agency must initiate a suspension or debarment proceeding against a grant applicant if their application contains a certification of seriously delinquent tax debt or if information from the Secretary of the Treasury shows that the certification is false. The head of an executive agency may waive the requirement for a suspension or debarment proceeding against a grant applicant if urgent and compelling circumstances significantly affecting the interests of the United States are present. If waived, a report must be submitted to relevant committees within 30 days. The Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, will provide a standard form for authorization to executive agencies. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget must revise regulations within 270 days to incorporate the requirements of this section. Definitions and special rules include the meaning of "executive agency" and "seriously delinquent tax debt." The term "seriously delinquent tax debt" refers to a Federal tax liability assessed by the Secretary of the Treasury under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, which can be collected through levy or court proceedings. Exceptions include debts being paid timely under an agreement or undergoing a collection due process hearing. The section applies to contracts and grants awarded 270 days after the enactment of the Act, involving seriously delinquent tax debts subject to continuous levy under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. SEC. 3. INELIGIBILITY OF NONCOMPLIANT TAXPAYERS FOR FEDERAL EMPLOYMENT. Amends Chapter 73 of title 5, United States Code by adding a new subchapter regarding the ineligibility of noncompliant taxpayers for federal employment. ``Seriously delinquent tax debt'' is defined as a Federal tax liability assessed by the Secretary of the Treasury under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, which can be collected by levy or court proceedings. Exclusions include debts being paid under an agreement, debts with pending collection due process hearings, and debts with continuous levies issued. Sec. 7382. Ineligibility for employment states that an individual is ineligible for employment if they have a seriously delinquent tax debt as defined by the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The terms 'employee' and 'agency' are also defined within this section. An individual is ineligible for employment if they have a seriously delinquent tax debt, fail to submit required certifications or authorization forms. Agencies must ensure applicants certify they have no such debt. The Office of Personnel Management, in consultation with the IRS, establishes regulations for the executive branch. The Office of Personnel Management, in consultation with the IRS, can promulgate regulations for the executive branch regarding eligibility for employment based on tax debt. Due process rights must be upheld, individuals have 180 days to demonstrate their debt status, and employees facing financial hardship can continue to serve. The Office of Personnel Management, in consultation with the IRS, can establish regulations for executive branch employment eligibility based on tax debt. Employees facing financial hardship can continue to serve if it's in the best interests of the United States, determined on a case-by-case basis. Each agency must review public records to check for tax liens filed under the Internal Revenue Code. Annual reports on exemptions requested and granted must be submitted to Congress. The agency can request an employee or applicant to authorize disclosure of tax debt information and any final determinations of misconduct. The Secretary of the Treasury will disclose the authorized information upon request. The Secretary of the Treasury will provide a standard authorization form for agencies to use. Confidentiality rules prohibit the use or disclosure of information for purposes other than administration. Adverse actions can be taken against employees who understate taxes or fail to file. Employees can face personnel actions if there is a final determination of willful failure to file taxes or willful understatement of tax liability. Personnel actions do not include administrative leave or paid leave without duty. Employees facing personnel actions for willful failure to file taxes or understatement of tax liability are entitled to specific procedures under regulations prescribed by the Office of Personnel Management. Ineligibility of noncompliant taxpayers for federal employment includes definitions, review of public records, confidentiality, and adverse actions for tax understatement or failure to file. Effective date is 270 days after enactment of the Act.
